item.title: Are You My Type?
item.dc:creator: Sianokie
item.description:
I like my men a certain way. Some people tend to think that I have daddy issues but the truth is, I simply think they’re easily relatable. When it comes to relationships of any kind, I always choose the easy way out. I prefer male friendships to female ones because they’re less dramatic and I...

The post Are You My Type? first appeared on The New Vibes.
item.content:encoded:
I like my men a certain way. Some people tend to think that I have daddy issues but the truth is, I simply think they’re easily relatable. When it comes to relationships of any kind, I always choose the easy way out. I prefer male friendships to female ones because they’re less dramatic and I keep an “everyone’s friend but no one’s friend” posture. I’m close to a few family members because they’re easy to get along with and they are the only ones I will ever care about. When it comes to men, I feel older people are less stressful to be with. We aren’t talking about any “Papa No” level because I’ve always placed a cap on 10yrs age gap and it’s never been about money. Before I digress, here are my specs in no particular order. I call this, “The 8S Theory”. 

1. Single!!!

2. Slightly older

3. Smart

4. Sexually attractive

5. Stable (Financially and emotionally)

6. Soft-Spoken

7. Sensitive

8. Spiritual

Before it became the 8S theory, it was the 4M theory (Maturity, Money, Muscular and Miscellaneous) but that wasn’t extensive enough especially if I wanted a future out of the relationship. Let me put it out there that I haven’t always gone out for my type. Sometimes I dated the direct opposite of what I wanted.

I’ve been with younger guys, I’ve been with guys I felt smarter than, I’ve been with guys with little or no attraction and I have even been with someone who was a financial mess. I’m a stickler for budgets, so to put it mildly, that relationship was a wreck!  I wasn’t really concerned about these qualities though, once there was some form of attraction, I could go a few months in the relationship. My previous relationships have always been complicated, undefined, entanglements, or just something to while away time. I believe not every relationship will end in marriage and there are some you just get into for the companionship and the whatnots.

Also read, “For Better, For Better”

Anyway, when I felt it was time to be in a committed relationship, I did a lot of thinking. I sat down one day, evaluated all the relationships I’ve been in, identified the patterns, and came up with the similarities in those that made it past 6 months (or 4).  That’s how I came up with 8S Theory and it seems to have worked pretty well for me. I’ve never been happier and more fulfilled in a relationship.

It’ll be fair to say I’m painting a picture of a perfect guy but I don’t think these qualities are far-fetched. My boyfriend checks all these boxes in addition to his tolerable flaws and I think an encouraging number of guys can check them too. Quite frankly, I don’t know which S I can compromise on. Spirituality? But I want that because I’m not too spiritual and someone has to bind those demons.

I want a smart person because I want someone who will have answers for me when I need them and as a hobby, I like to listen to guys intelligently talk about their jobs. I like a slightly older and mature person because from my experience, dating someone younger or even your age mate forces you to mother someone else’s son and check up on him as though he’s plantain that you’re frying. It’s exhausting. I like them financially stable because this girl here likes to afford things. Whether it’s with my money or my man’s.

I find myself being attracted to seemingly shy guys. They’re strong, confident, and brave in a vulnerable kind of way. (Does this even make sense?) Sensitive guys are normally in touch with their feminine sides and they can most often understand how I feel. For sexual attraction! If it’s not there, then why are we wasting our time? Bottom line is, I have a reason for every S and each is very important.

When you talk about having a type, people think you’re being typical. In fact, people even take offense when you say they aren’t your type. But rather than take offense, why don’t you take a minute to ask what the type entails. If you don’t fit into the category, wouldn’t you be glad you didn’t start something that was going to head nowhere? Or you’d want someone to date you out of politeness? People know themselves and know what types of people work for them. Let’s allow them to express their preferences and let’s take it in good faith if we’re not what they want. If there’s no spark, there just isn’t.

No need to force it. If you don’t have a type too, that sounds lucky yet dangerous at the same time. As in, anything works for you? Wow! Starting today, come up with a list. It might require some Rubik’s Cube-solving skills but it’s totally worth it and it’ll help you avoid avoidable mistakes. If you have a type that’s realistic, I want to encourage you that your type exists.

So don’t settle.

_____________________________________________________

RELATIONSHIP     LIFESTYLE    CANDID VIBEZ    LOVE      QUALITIES

MARRIAGE     DIVORCE    COMPATIBILITY    PERFECT MATCH 

_____________________________________________________
